article.title: Outdated Samsung handset linked to fatal emergency call failure in Australia

experiments.title: Outdated Samsung handset linked to fatal emergency call failure in Australia
experiments.tldr_markdown:
Bottom line: A Sydney death is linked to an outdated Samsung phone that couldn’t reach 000; TPG says its network worked, blames old device software, and cites mandated blocks for unpatched handsets. Samsung urges immediate updates or replacements.

# TL;DR

- **What happened:** A Lebara/TPG customer in Sydney died after their Samsung couldn’t connect to 000. TPG disclosed the incident to the ASX, saying its network was fully operational and pointing to the phone’s outdated software as the cause. [Statement](https://wcsecure.weblink.com.au/pdf/TPG/03024249.pdf)
- **Devices at risk:** Samsung says “certain older devices” need updating/replacing to make Triple Zero calls; it lists dozens of affected models (e.g., Galaxy S7, Note 5). [Device list](https://www.samsung.com/au/support/mobile-devices/issue-with-some-older-galaxy-devices-calling-triple-zero/)
- **Warnings and compliance:** TPG says it warned impacted users multiple times, most recently Nov 7. Under federal rules, carriers must block handsets that still can’t complete 000 after 28–35 days unpatched; TPG says it followed this.
- **Industry context:** Telstra also warned last month about older, non-upgradeable Samsung phones failing 000 and facing mandatory blocking nationwide. [Telstra note](https://www.telstra.com.au/exchange/older-mobile-devices-calling-triple-zero-)
- **Investigation and notifications:** TPG has alerted federal and state authorities, ACMA, and the Triple Zero Custodian; probe ongoing.
- **Samsung response (update):** Offers condolences; says it’s working with carriers; urges customers to keep devices updated or replace if required.
- **Backdrop:** Earlier this year, Optus admitted a firewall update blocked emergency calls for 14 hours, linked to three deaths. [Report](https://www.theregister.com/2025/09/21/optus_emergency_call_incident/)
- **TPG CEO:** 
  > “This is a tragic incident... We urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay.”

experiments.title: Outdated Samsung handset linked to fatal emergency call failure in Australia
experiments.tldr_markdown:
Bottom line: A Sydney resident died after an older Samsung phone, left on outdated software, couldn’t call 000; carrier TPG says its network was fine, blames a known compatibility issue on legacy Galaxy models, and notes it followed rules that can block unpatched devices from emergency calling.

## What happened
- A Lebara (on TPG) customer died after failing to reach 000; TPG’s ASX filing says its network was operational and early probes point to a Samsung device running software no longer compatible with emergency calling ([ASX PDF](https://wcsecure.weblink.com.au/pdf/TPG/03024249.pdf)).
- Samsung has flagged “certain older devices” and lists models requiring updates or replacement to ensure Triple Zero calls work (e.g., Galaxy S7/Note 5 series) ([Samsung list](https://www.samsung.com/au/support/mobile-devices/issue-with-some-older-galaxy-devices-calling-triple-zero/)).
- TPG says it warned affected users multiple times, most recently Nov 7; the victim’s handset wasn’t updated.

## Policy, blame, and warnings
- Under Australia’s Emergency Service Call Determination, operators must block handsets that can’t complete 000 if not fixed within 28–35 days after first warning; TPG says it complied.
- Telstra previously warned that older, non‑upgradeable Samsung devices could fail 000 and face mandatory blocking across all networks ([Telstra post](https://www.telstra.com.au/exchange/older-mobile-devices-calling-triple-zero-)).
- TPG notified federal/state authorities, ACMA, and the Triple Zero Custodian; disclosure made due to public concern over 000 reliability.

## Statements and context
- CEO Iñaki Berroeta: 
> “This is a tragic incident... We urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay.”
- Samsung (post‑publication): expressed condolences; urged customers to keep devices updated and said it’s working with carriers to ensure reliability.
- Context: Optus earlier admitted a firewall update blocked emergency calls for 14 hours, linked to three deaths ([report](https://www.theregister.com/2025/09/21/optus_emergency_call_incident/)).

experiments.title: Outdated Samsung handset linked to fatal emergency call failure in Australia
experiments.tldr_markdown:
**Bottom line:** An Australian died after an old Samsung phone couldn’t call 000. The carrier says its network worked; outdated Samsung software broke emergency calling. Regulators force telcos to block such unpatched phones – and this device was in that danger zone.

---

# TL;DR – Fatal 000 Failure on Outdated Samsung

- **Incident:**  
  A Sydney resident using a **Lebara service on TPG’s network** died after their Samsung handset **failed to connect to 000**, Australia’s emergency number.

- **Cause (early findings):**  
  TPG told the ASX in a [statement](https://wcsecure.weblink.com.au/pdf/TPG/03024249.pdf) its network was **fully operational**; the problem likely stemmed from the handset’s **old Samsung software no longer compatible with emergency calls**.

- **Affected devices:**  
  Samsung has [listed dozens of older Galaxy models](https://www.samsung.com/au/support/mobile-devices/issue-with-some-older-galaxy-devices-calling-triple-zero/), including **Galaxy S7 and Note 5 series**, that must be **updated or replaced** to reliably reach Triple Zero.

- **Warnings and non-compliance:**  
  TPG says it had **repeatedly warned customers** with flagged Samsung models to update, with the latest alert on **November 7**.  
  > "Customer safety remains our highest priority... We urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay."

- **Regulatory backdrop:**  
  Under Australia’s **Emergency Service Call Determination**, carriers **must block** handsets that remain unable to complete 000 calls **28–35 days** after first warning. TPG insists it complied with these rules.

- **Broader concern:**  
  TPG disclosed the case due to **growing public anxiety about emergency call reliability**, following earlier failures such as **Optus’s 14‑hour 000 outage** linked to **three deaths** ([Reg story](https://www.theregister.com/2025/09/21/optus_emergency_call_incident/)).

- **Industry response:**  
  - **Telstra** has already [warned](https://www.telstra.com.au/exchange/older-mobile-devices-calling-triple-zero-) that older, non‑upgradeable Samsung phones may **fail 000 calls** and face **mandatory blocking** on all networks.  
  - **Samsung**, in a post-publication statement, said it was **“deeply saddened”**, is working with carriers to ensure reliability in emergencies, and **strongly urges users to keep devices fully updated**, noting carriers have notified affected customers with instructions.

- **Government and oversight:**  
  TPG says it has informed the **federal communications minister, state authorities, the ACMA, and the Triple Zero Custodian** as the investigation continues.

experiments.title: Outdated Samsung handset linked to fatal emergency call failure in Australia
experiments.tldr_markdown:
**Bottom line:** An Australian died after their Samsung phone couldn’t dial 000; telco TPG blames outdated Samsung software on older Galaxy devices, not its network, and regulators may now probe emergency-call reliability across carriers and handsets.

---

# TL;DR

## What happened

- **A Sydney resident died** when their Samsung handset failed to connect to **000**, Australia’s main emergency number, while using a **Lebara service on TPG’s network**.
- **TPG says its network was fully operational** and early investigation points to **Samsung handset software that’s no longer compatible with emergency calling**.

## Devices and software at fault

- **Samsung has acknowledged an issue on “certain older devices”** and published a list of affected models that must be **updated or replaced** to ensure 000 works, including **Galaxy S7 and Note 5 series**.
- The dead customer’s phone was on that list and **had not been updated despite multiple warnings** from TPG, the last on **November 7**.
- Telstra separately [warned](https://www.telstra.com.au/exchange/older-mobile-devices-calling-triple-zero-) that **older, non-upgradeable Samsung phones** may also fail when calling 000 and would be **blocked from all Australian networks** if not fixed.

## Regulatory obligations and telco stance

- Under Australia’s **Emergency Service Call Determination**, operators must **block handsets that can’t complete 000 calls** if they stay unpatched **28–35 days after the first warning**.  
- TPG says it **followed this rule** and disclosed the incident to the **ASX** due to **“heightened public concern”** over emergency call reliability.
- TPG has notified the **federal communications minister, state authorities, ACMA, and the Triple Zero Custodian** and continues to investigate.
- CEO Iñaki Berroeta stressed:
  > "This is a tragic incident... We urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay."

## Samsung’s response

- In a later statement, Samsung expressed condolences and said it is **“working closely with our carrier partners”** to ensure reliable operation in emergencies.
- It strongly urged customers to **keep devices updated**:
  > "We strongly encourage customers to keep their mobile devices updated with the latest software, as this is critical to maintaining the highest standards of safety, security, and performance."

## Bigger picture: 000 reliability under scrutiny

- The incident comes after **Optus admitted** a **firewall update** earlier this year **knocked out emergency calling for 14 hours**, an outage **linked to three deaths**.
- Combined, these failures highlight **systemic fragility in Australia’s emergency-call ecosystem**—from **network changes** to **aging, unpatched handsets**—with mounting **public and regulatory pressure** on both telcos and handset makers.
